children.subject:
I took EE122 last semester and it was with a visiting professor. Honestly, it starts off pretty slow (with the standard analogy of mailing letters to sending messages over the internet) and picks up quickly into congestion control (ex. TCP slow start), time division multiplexing, slotted aloha, routers, Bellman-Ford & Dijkstra, bit encodings, etc. Projects were in C and used Berkeley Sockets API (which also no one uses anymore so finding help online is difficult too). I haven't taken CS 168, so I don't know the details, but it gets to be a lot more math than actual internet protocol comprehension.

A final note - not to deter anyone from taking this course - is you should only really, really, really only take EE122 if you are super interested in communication networks and will find further uses for what you learned in this class after taking it. For example, using WireShark stuff.

I guess this is the final, final note, but I took it with a visiting professor, so I'm not sure what EE122 will really be like.

EE 123 used to be more CS-oriented in the Fall and more EE-oriented in the Spring. Last year, they decided to just rename the Fall version so that it was in the CS department to make that distinction much clearer. I felt like CS 168 was worth taking, because knowing how the Internet works is a big part of being a CS major, and there was so much material to learn that I wouldn't have the time or patience to learn it all on my own otherwise. I'm sure EE 122 (in the Spring) is similar to CS 168 in the high-level concepts, but as for the projects and technical details, they delve farther into the lower-level properties of the Internet.
I'd suggest looking at recent course websites for EE122 to get the answer to questions of this nature:  http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/education/courses.shtml
Is EE122 also only focused on the internet? Or does it teach telecommunications?
This is a great question to ask the EE faculty in faculty advising. or Professor Parekh since since he's teaching it next semester.

Why does the course description of EE 122 mention cellular networks and wireless communication, but no one else has mentioned learning that? I am seeking a telecommunications course but I'm not sure if EE122 is the class I'm looking for

history.content:
in short CS 168 is all the CS/software related topics regarding networks/internet. More here: https://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs168/fa15/ EE 122 is all the hardware/EE related concepts regarding networking. The topics include graph theory, Markov chains, queuing, optimization techniques, the physical and link layers, switching, transport, cellular networks and Wi-Fi. 

From Professor Waldrand: 

The main difference between these two courses is that EE122 explores
the performance aspects of networks  in more depth whereas CS168
focuses more on the programing of network applications.

Both courses explain the main protocols (TCP/IP, DNS, WiFi, etc).
EE122 covers elements of network programming with a small project.
CS168 has a more comprehensive network programming project.

CS70 is a sufficient preparation for EE122

in short CS 168 is all the CS/software related topics regarding networks/internet. More here: https://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs168/fa15/ EE 122 is all the hardware/EE related concepts regarding networking. The topics include graph theory, Markov chains, queuing, optimization techniques, the physical and link layers, switching, transport, cellular networks and Wi-Fi.

children.subject: yep, that's totally fine as long as you have at least CS70 (assumes you've also taken math 54)
Would EE122 be a good class for my first EECS upper div (and as a second year)? What prerequisite classes would help a lot for 122?
